entry.title: Reduct Storage v0.8.0 has been released
entry.summary:
Hey everyone, I'm proud to announce that Reduct Storage v0.8.0 was released yesterday. This release doesn't provide new features, but it has some improvements that are worth to be noticed. We met a problem deploying the storage engine on a NAS device because it didn't work with the GitHub registry. Now, all releases are pushed to DockerHub additionally. Preferable way to use the engine is: docker run -p 8383:8383 -v ${PWD}/data:/data reductstorage/engine:latest
Previously, a client had to ask an access token by using an API token and the GET /auth/refresh endpoint: # Take a temporal access token by using the API token curl -X POST --header "Authorization: Bearer ${API_TOKEN}" -a https://play.reduct-storage.dev/auth/refresh
# Create a bucket curl -d "{\"quota_type\":\"FIFO\", \"quota_size\":10000}" \ -X POST \ --header "Authorization: Bearer ${ACCESS_TOKEN}" \ -a https://play.reduct-storage.dev/b/my_data
The issue with this approach is described here. Now, GET /auth/refresh is deprecated, and the preferable approach is: # Take a temporal access token by using the API token export API_TOKEN=reduct
# Create a bucket curl -d "{\"quota_type\":\"FIFO\", \"quota_size\":10000}" \ -X POST \ --header "Authorization: Bearer ${API_TOKEN}" \ -a https://play.reduct-storage.dev/b/my_data

entry.title: The Modern Refresher to React Development in 2022
entry.summary:
There‚Äôs no denying that React is the most popular web framework out there. This fact is even proven by StackOverFlow‚Äôs recent survey polling thousands of developers.
Having already covered Vue development in our prior article in this series comparing web frameworks, it‚Äôs only fair to give React an equal chance by showing-off its features and community-made treasures. And while React is backed by multi-trillion dollar company, it‚Äôs open-source community is still one of the key factors in its large success. In this article, we‚Äôll go through the React development process for beginners and developers who just need a quick refresher. We‚Äôll build a website for publicly sharing short-messages, called ‚Äúithink‚Äù. It‚Äôs like Twitter, but with no accounts and you can‚Äôt delete what you post. / ‚Ä¶

‰ªª‰ΩïËÄÉËôëÂú®ÂºÄÊ∫êÈ¢ÜÂüüÂèëÂ±ïÁöÑ‰∫∫ÈÉΩÂÖ∑ÊúâÊó†ÈôêÁöÑÂèØËÉΩÊÄß„ÄÇ‰∏ãÈù¢ÊòØÊàëÁöÑÊïÖ‰∫ã„ÄÇ
ÂΩì‰∫∫‰ª¨ÈóÆÊàëÊúÄÂñúÊ¨¢ÂºÄÊ∫êÁöÑ‰ªÄ‰πàÊó∂ÔºåÊàëÁöÑÂõûÁ≠îÂæàÁÆÄÂçïÔºöÈÇ£Â∞±ÊòØ¬†ÂºÄÊîæÊÄß¬†„ÄÇÂú®ÂºÄÊ∫ê‰∏≠ÔºåÁ§æÂå∫ÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂíåË¥°ÁåÆËÄÖÊâÄÂÅöÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊòØÂú®ÂÖ¨ÂÖ±È¢ÜÂüüÁöÑÔºåÊâÄÊúâ‰∫∫ÈÉΩËÉΩÁúãÂà∞Âπ∂‰ªé‰∏≠ÂèóÁõä„ÄÇÊàëÂØπËøô‰∏ÄÁêÜÂøµÁà±‰∏çÈáäÊâã„ÄÇ
ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ë‰∫∫ÂèØ‰ª•ÂØπ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂä≥Âä®ÊàêÊûúËøôÊ†∑ËØ¥ÔºüÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ë‰∫∫Ôºå‰πüËÆ∏Âú® 50 Âπ¥ÂêéÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÂõûËøáÂ§¥Êù•ËØ¥Ôºö‚ÄúÁúãÁúãÊàëÈÇ£Â§©ÂÜôÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÊúâÂá†Áôæ/Âá†ÂçÉ/Âá†‰∏á‰∫∫‰ªé‰∏≠ÂèóÁõä„ÄÇ‚ÄùÊàëËßâÂæóËøôÊØî‰ªé‰∫ãÈÇ£‰∫õÂØπ‰∏ñÁïå‰∏äÂ§ßÂ§öÊï∞‰∫∫Êù•ËØ¥ÈÉΩÊòØÈöêÁßòÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•‰ΩúÊõ¥‰ª§‰∫∫Êó†ÊØîÂÖ¥Â•ã„ÄÇ
ÊàëÂæàÂπ∏ËøêÔºåÊàëÁöÑÂ∑•‰Ωú‰ΩøÊàëÁΩÆË∫´‰∫é‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂºÄÊ∫êÂíå‰ºÅ‰∏ö‰∫§ÂèâÁöÑÊúâË∂£È¢ÜÂüü‰∏≠„ÄÇÂ¶Ç‰ªäÔºåÊàëÊòØ¬†OpenNMS ÈõÜÂõ¢¬†ÁöÑÈ¶ñÂ∏≠ÊäÄÊúØÂÆòÔºåËøôÂÆ∂ÂÖ¨Âè∏Ë¥üË¥£Áª¥Êä§¬†OpenNMS È°πÁõÆ„ÄÇOpenNMS ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™È¢ÜÂÖàÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êÁΩëÁªúÁõëÊéßÂíåÁÆ°ÁêÜÂπ≥Âè∞„ÄÇ
ËôΩÁÑ∂ÊàëÁé∞Âú®ÁöÑËßíËâ≤ËÆ©ÊàëÁâ¢Áâ¢ÊâéÊ†π‰∫éÂºÄÊ∫êÈ¢ÜÂüüÔºå‰ΩÜÊàëÊòØ‰ª•Áî®Êà∑ÂíåË¥°ÁåÆËÄÖË∫´‰ªΩÂºÄÂßãÁöÑ„ÄÇ
2007 Âπ¥ÔºåÊàëÂæóÂà∞‰∫ÜÊàëÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰ªΩÁúüÊ≠£ÁöÑÊäÄÊúØÂ∑•‰ΩúÔºåÂú®Âä†ÊãøÂ§ßËíôÁâπÂà©Â∞îÁöÑÁîµ‰ø°ÊúçÂä°Êèê‰æõÂïÜ Datavalet ÊäÄÊúØÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ªé‰∫ãÁΩëÁªúÂàÜÊûê„ÄÇÂú®‰∫îÂπ¥ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ÂÜÖÔºåÊàëÊàêÈïø‰∏∫Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÊû∂ÊûÑÂ∏àÔºå‰ªªÂä°ÊòØÂ∏ÆÂä©ÂÖ¨Âè∏ÈÄâÊã©ÁΩëÁªúÁÆ°ÁêÜËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ÈÄâÊã©‰∫Ü OpenNMSÔºåÊ≠£ÊòØÈÄöËøáËøôÊ¨°ÁªèÂéÜÔºåÊàëËÆ§ËØÜÂà∞‰∫ÜÂºÄÊ∫êÁöÑÁúüÊ≠£ÂäõÈáè„ÄÇ
Âú®Âπ≥Âè∞‰∏äÁ∫øÊó∂ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèëÁé∞‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∫õÁº∫Â§±ÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÔºåËøô‰∫õÂäüËÉΩÂ∞ÜÊúâÂä©‰∫é‰ºòÂåñÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰ΩìÈ™å„ÄÇ‰∏Ä‰ΩçÊù•Ëá™ OpenNMS ÈõÜÂõ¢ÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®Âú®Áé∞Âú∫Â∏ÆÂä©Êàë‰ª¨ËøõË°åÈÉ®ÁΩ≤ÔºåÂπ∂Âª∫ËÆÆÊàëÂèÇÂä†Á§æÂå∫Âç≥Â∞Ü‰∏æË°åÁöÑ DevJamÔºå‰∏éÊ†∏ÂøÉÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫Âëò‰∏ÄËµ∑Âª∫Á´ãÊàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÁöÑÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇ
Âú® DevJam ÊúüÈó¥ÔºåÊàëÂæàÂø´Â∞±ËûçÂÖ•‰∫ÜÂõ¢ÈòüÂíåÁ§æÂå∫„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨Âç∑Ëµ∑Ë¢ñÂ≠êÔºåÂºÄÂßãÁºñÁ†ÅÔºå‰ª•ÂàõÂª∫ Datavalet ÊâÄÈúÄÁöÑÂ¢ûÂº∫ÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇÂú®Âá†Â§©‰πãÂÜÖÔºåËøô‰∏™ÈôÑÂä†ÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÂ∞±ÂáÜÂ§áÂ•Ω‰∫Ü„ÄÇËøôÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰ª§‰∫∫ÊÉäÂèπÁöÑÂèòÈù©ÊÄßÁªèÂéÜÔºåËÆ©ÊàëÁúüÊ≠£ÁúãÂà∞‰∫ÜÂºÄÊ∫êÁöÑÂäõÈáè„ÄÇ
‰∏ÄÂπ¥ÂêéÔºåÊàëÁ¶ªËÅå‰∫ÜÔºåÂú®Â∫∑ÁßëËø™‰∫öÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÂÖ®Êó•Âà∂Â≠¶‰π†Êï∞Â≠¶„ÄÇÊ≠£ÊòØÂú®ÈÇ£ÈáåÔºåÊàëÂÜçÊ¨°ÊúâÊú∫‰ºö‰∏é OpenNMS Âõ¢ÈòüÂêà‰ΩúÔºåËøô‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊòØÂú®ËØ•Âπ¥ÁöÑË∞∑Ê≠å‰ª£Á†Å‰πãÂ§èÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™È°πÁõÆ‰∏ä„ÄÇÂú®Ëøô‰∏™Âπ¥Â∫¶ËÆ°Âàí‰∏≠ÔºåÂèÇ‰∏éËÄÖÁöÑÁõÆÊ†áÊòØÊàêÂäüÂÆåÊàêÂºÄÊ∫êËΩØ‰ª∂ÂºÄÂèëÈ°πÁõÆ„ÄÇ
‰ª£Á†Å‰πãÂ§èÂØπÊàëÊù•ËØ¥ÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊîπÂèòËÅå‰∏öÁîüÊ∂ØÁöÑÁªèÂéÜ„ÄÇOpenNMS ÁöÑ‰∏§‰ΩçË¥üË¥£‰∫∫ÂèÇÂä†‰∫ÜÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆÊºîÁ§∫Ôºå‰∏ÄÂπ¥ÂêéÔºåOpenNMS Âõ¢ÈòüÈÇÄËØ∑Êàë‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏ÄÂêçÂÖ®Ê†àÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÂä†ÂÖ•„ÄÇ

entry.title: Merge Triplets to Form Target Triplet
Add Google Authentication to your NextJs project using NextAuth.js
entry.summary:
Next-Auth is a complete open-source authentication for Next.Js applications. You can learn more about it here. Here in this blog tutorial, I will show you how you can use NextAuth.js in your NextJs project to add Google authentication. In this particular tutorial I am using Typescript but you can follow it for Javascript. You can install it using yarn or using npm. yarn add next-auth
npm install next-auth
To add NextAuth.js in your project you need to first create [...nextauth].ts inside you pages/api/auth. // pages/api/auth/[...nextauth].ts
import NextAuth, { NextAuthOptions } from 'next-auth' import GoogleProvider from 'next-auth/providers/google'
export const authOptions: NextAuthOptions = { providers: [ GoogleProvider({ clientId: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID‚Ä¶

entry.title: Linux Mint 21 Vanessa released - New features and changes
entry.summary: Linux mint version 21 code named Vanessa was released recently based on Ubuntu 22.04 which is a long term support release and will be supported until 2027. It comes with updated software and brings refinements and many new features to make your desktop experience more comfortable. Let us take a look at some of the major changes and updates. In Linux Mint 21 Blueman replaces Blueberry. Blueberry depended on gnome-bluetooth, which was developed exclusively for GNOME. In contrast, Blueman relies on the standard Bluez stack which works everywhere and can even be used or queried from the command line. Blueman's UI was polished for mint and looks much better than before. Blueman also received support for many symbolic icons which gives it a much more refined look and integrates it with other m‚Ä¶

entry.title: 9 useful code snippets for everyday JavaScript development || Part 2
Self Host Heroku Alternative
entry.summary:
Heroku is removing their free tier, as a free PaaS, its free tier is very friendly for #webdev. As a dev, I feel a bit sad. üò•
However, don't need to be panic, because there are alternative for Heroku. Caprover
CapRover is an extremely easy to use app/database deployment & web server manager for your NodeJS, Python, PHP, ASP.NET, Ruby, MySQL, MongoDB, Postgres, WordPress (and etc...) applications! It is a docker compose based solution, so basically you can run any application in any language you prefer I moved my apps from Heroku to Caprover and used it for about 2 years. It does not give me any problems. It was hosted on an AWS EC2 t3a.micro, it costs me about $60 per year. Otherwise, Digital Ocean could be a good option to host Caprover too, this is a tutorial to create a Digital Oce‚Ä¶

entry.title: My favorite open source library for analyzing music files
entry.summary:
My favorite open source library for analyzing music files Chris Hermansen Sat, 08/27/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this In my previous article, I created a framework for analyzing the directories and subdirectories of music files, using the groovy.File class, which extends and streamlines java.File and simplifies its use. In this article, I use the open source JAudiotagger library to analyze the tags of the music files in the music directory and subdirectories. Be sure to read the first article in this series if you intend to follow along. Install Java and Groovy Groovy is based on Java, and requires a Java installation. Both a recent and decent version of Java and Groovy might be in your Linux distribution's repositories. Groovy can also be installed directly from ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg won‚Äôt be deposed over the Cambridge Analytica scandal
entry.summary:
Illustration by William Joel / The Verge
Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg were in line to give hours of depositions in response to a lawsuit over Facebook and the Cambridge Analytica data privacy scandal, but now that won‚Äôt happen ‚Äî the company has reached a settlement agreement with the plaintiffs. As reported earlier by Reuters, a court filing reveals the parties have reached an agreement in principle and requested a stay of 60 days to finalize their written agreement. Without the settlement and stay, they would have been deposed before September 20th. You can read the document for yourself below, but so far, there are no details about the terms of the agreement. Meta, as the company is now known, declined to comment via a spokesperson, while lawyers for the plaintiffs... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Netflix‚Äôs ad-supported tier could cost between $7 and $9 per month
entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
Netflix‚Äôs forthcoming ad-supported tier may cost between $7 and $9 per month, according to a report from Bloomberg. Depending on which plan you currently pay for, that could be a significant savings; the company currently offers plans at $9.99, $15.49, and $19.99 per month. After the company reported that it lost subscribers for the first time in more than a decade, co-CEO Reed Hastings indicated in April the company was ready to consider a cheaper offering supported by advertising, despite years of spurning the idea of ads. Co-CEO Ted Sarandos confirmed the ad tier was in the works in June, and Netflix announced Microsoft as the technological partner helping to deliver ads in July. Perhaps unsurprisingly, the ad-supported tier will... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Meta‚Äôs VP of Horizon is leaving the company
entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
Meta‚Äôs Vivek Sharma, the company‚Äôs VP of its Horizon social VR platform, is leaving the company, as reported by Reuters. Meta spokesperson Bryan Pope confirmed Sharma‚Äôs departure to The Verge and said that Sharma is leaving to pursue an unrelated career opportunity. Sharma‚Äôs departure is happening at a somewhat awkward time for Horizon. The metaverse is an enormous bet for Meta, with Horizon as one of its centerpieces, but the whole effort became something of a meme last week. To help promote Horizon Worlds‚Äô launch in France and Spain, CEO Mark Zuckerberg posted a screenshot in Horizon that prominently featured his dead-eyed avatar, which nearly instantly became a popular joke around the internet. Zuckerberg shared concept art of a more... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Twitter shopping features could lead to ‚Äòindividual or societal harm,‚Äô according to leaked memo
entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
Shopping features on Twitter pose content moderation risks and could be used ‚Äúin a way that leads to individual or societal harm,‚Äù according to an internal memo sent to a team of Twitter employees. The memo, a portion of which was obtained by The Verge, was sent in early July to a group of Twitter employees across various teams, according to a person with knowledge of it. In the email, some existing and not-yet-released features of Twitter shopping are categorized as high risk, with the email warning that content moderation hasn‚Äôt been prioritized in shopping. First rolled out last summer, Twitter shopping allows brands to list items for sale and pin a handful of products at the top of a merchant‚Äôs profile. Unlike similar features on... Continue reading‚Ä¶

The SLS is finally ready for its big debut Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: PSA: Bandcamp Fridays are coming back
entry.summary:
Time to buy some jams. | Photo by Roy Rochlin/Getty Images
Bandcamp is bringing back its Bandcamp Fridays promotion where it waives its cut of any money you spend buying music from artists or their labels on its marketplace. Historically, the company ran the promotion on the first Friday of every month, and that appears to be the case this time around, too. According to its update page, it has Bandcamp Fridays scheduled for September 2nd, October 7th, November 4th, and December 2nd. Bandcamp says that when you buy music during a Bandcamp Friday, 93 percent of that money goes to the artist or label on average (with the rest going to payment processing fees). That‚Äôs compared to an average of 82 percent the rest of the time. It started the promotion in 2020 in response to the pandemic‚Äôs impact on... Continue reading‚Ä¶

Earlier this week, LastPass started notifying its users of a ‚Äúrecent security incident‚Äù where an ‚Äúunauthorized party‚Äù used a compromised developer account to access parts of its password manager‚Äôs source code and ‚Äúsome proprietary LastPass technical information.‚Äù In a letter to its users, the company‚Äôs CEO Karim Toubba explains that its investigation hasn‚Äôt turned up evidence that any user data or encrypted passwords were accessed. Toubba continues on to explain that the company has ‚Äúimplemented additional enhanced security measures‚Äù after containing the breach, which it detected two weeks ago. Yesterday we launched open testing of the MVP of our timesharing platform. So far, the product is a database that stores parameters of participants such as name, time zone, profession, competencies, experience, fields of interest, learning needs, teaching abilities, and expert's contacts for the public.
But the main version will become an all-in-one tool for time management with the following features:‚Ä® - Task management‚Ä® - Sale of meetings from personal schedules‚Ä® - Employee scheduling and time tracking‚Ä®- Dialogues and group chats‚Ä® - Reviews and ratings system‚Ä® - Internal hiring and recommendations ‚Ä®- Project‚Äôs newsfeed‚Ä® - Transparent reward system
Now we really need your feedback, so guys, please check our MVP and feel free to write everything you think about the whole concept. Thank you very much in advance! ‚Äù

entry.title: Feds are thinking about an antitrust case against Apple
entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
So far, the biggest tech antitrust cases have focused on Facebook and Google ‚Äî but Apple may soon be joining the pack. Politico is reporting that the Department of Justice is in the early stages of drafting an antitrust case against Apple, alleging that the company ‚Äúabused its market power to stifle smaller tech companies, including app developers and competing hardware makers.‚Äù It would be the first such case against Apple by a US federal agency, although European antitrust regulators have raised similar cases over the company‚Äôs App Store fees and the iPhone‚Äôs treatment of tap-to-pay technology. The company has also fended off a number of civil cases from rival companies ‚Äî most notably, the App Store challenge from Epic Games, which... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Democrats are getting comfortable clowning on Republicans online
entry.summary:
Rob Flaherty, White House director of digital strategy
There‚Äôs only a few weeks until the midterms, and President Joe Biden is starting beef on Twitter. Earlier this week, Biden announced that the federal government would cancel up to $20,000 worth of federal student loans for millions of borrowers. While the internet‚Äôs reaction to the news was typical, the White House‚Äôs response to that reaction was not. On Thursday, the White House‚Äôs official Twitter account called out Republican lawmakers who spent the last few days criticizing the administration‚Äôs student loan forgiveness plan. In a series of tweets, the White House name-dropped Republicans like Reps. 2 readers like this 2 readers like this Lately, I‚Äôve been looking at how Groovy streamlines the slight clunkiness of Java. In this article, I begin a short series to demonstrate Groovy scripting by creating a tool to analyze my music directory. In this article, I demonstrate how the groovy.File class extends and streamlines java.File and simplifies its use. This provides a framework for looking at the contents of a music folder to ensure that expected content (for example, a cover.jpg file) is in place. I use the JAudiotagger library to analyze the tags of any music files. Install Java and Groovy Groovy is based on Java and requires a Java installation. entry.title: My open source journey from user to contributor to CTO
entry.summary:
My open source journey from user to contributor to CTO Jesse White Fri, 08/26/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this When people ask me what I love most about open source, my answer is simple: It's the openness. With open source, the work that community developers and contributors do is in the public domain for all to see and benefit from. I couldn't love that philosophy more. How many people can say that about the fruits of their labor? How many, perhaps 50 years from now, can look back and say, "Check out the code I wrote that day that hundreds/thousands/tens of thousands benefited from." I find that infinitely more exciting than working on software that's hidden from most of the world. I'm fortunate that my job puts me in the middle of an interesting area where open ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Life Goals OS ‚Äî A guide and template for managing personal goals with Notion
entry.summary:
What does it do?
Life Goals OS is part guide part product. It breaks down what goal-setting is about and how it works. It guides you through a simple workflow to brainstorm, define, progress, review and accomplish your goals. It‚Äôs set up as an iterative system to get better at getting better.
What‚Äôs included?
- Resources and guides on goal-setting based on work of various authors such as Stephen Covey, Bill Burnett & Dave Evans, Naval Ravikant and Chris Bailey - A clean dashboard for your goals which you can orient your existing goal management systems around - Checklists and templates that guide you through the processes of setting and checking in with your goals.
Why did I make it?
It was the scratch-your-own-itch-factor. Well, more than just my own itch. Whenever I ask my team and friends what they struggle with the most it's unanimously goal setting. Wat goals should I set? How do I define good goals? How do I stay on track? As COO and Product Manager at our 40-employee business I landed on OKRs as the goal-setting framework of preference. So, After having tried and tested the system for the past years it felt like the right thing to launch as my first indie-project.
I‚Äôve been eager to start with independent projects for a while now. As ferocious Product Hunt follower it‚Äôs incredibly exciting to be on the launching-end for the first time. I‚Äôm grateful for my colleagues and online-friends who‚Äôve encouraged me to take this step. And, a massive shout out to the Product Hunt community for nurturing such a great launch pad.
In celebration of the launch all Product Hunters get 50% off with code: ph50
I‚Äôm excited to see your feedback and happy to answer any questions you might have! ‚Äù
Discussion | Link

entry.title: Happy birthday, Linux! Here are 6 Linux origin stories
entry.summary:
Happy birthday, Linux! Here are 6 Linux origin stories AmyJune Hineline Thu, 08/25/2022 - 08:01
4 readers like this 4 readers like this On August 25, 1991, Linux 0.01 was announced. All of us have a story to tell about Linux. I told my story a couple of months ago, but for those who weren't here: My first exposure to Linux was when my grassroots hospice organization moved from paper to digital charting. We didn't have the funding to get something proprietary, but the IT department had Linux set up on our old machine, and we used the GNOME desktop and OpenOffice to start our journey in creating digital assets. I recently asked some Opensource.com authors this simple question: What was your first Linux experience? From VAX to Linux For my junior year of high school, I was shipped off t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Keyframes.app v2 ‚Äî Simple dev tools for keyframes, colors, shadows, & more
entry.summary:
@keyframes are some of the things I use most frequently, so I wanted to build them the way I thought they should be. My goal was to create simple tools that are private, local, customizable, and easy to use, without all the annoying junk like massive ads, popups, invasive tracking, or forced social media integration.
üëæ CSS @Keyframe Animation Editor A tool that gives you a timeline (like movie editing software) to easily create and preview CSS animations.
‚ùê Box-Shadow generator Simply move some sliders to adjust your shadow, add multiple layers, then get the CSS.
üé® Colors Create & convert colors, create color palettes, view color contrast and colorblindness, create gradients, and share your palettes.
‚å®Ô∏è Character codes Search for and easily copy special character CSS and HTML values.
üëã What makes it stand out: ‚Ä¢ It's free - all features. ‚Ä¢ It's private & local - Keyframes only uses Local Storage, and there are no 3rd party trackers or ad networks. It's also open source, so you can verify. ‚Ä¢ The UI is customizable - the theme, font, borders, and behaviors like confirmation dialogues and tooltips can be disabled. ‚Ä¢ Created from scratch - no frontend frameworks or 3rd-party libraries let me get everything just how I wanted it.
So if you're a developer or designer who works with CSS a lot, I hope these tools can be useful and save you some time. I'll be adding more tools over the coming weeks - so keep an eye out!
I'd love to hear any questions, suggestions, ideas for other tools, criticism, or anything else you have to say! ‚Äù
Discussion | Link

entry.title: Using eBPF for network observability in the cloud
entry.summary:
Using eBPF for network observability in the cloud Pravein Govind‚Ä¶ Thu, 08/25/2022 - 03:00
Register or Login to like Register or Login to like Observability is the ability to know and interpret the current state of a deployment, and a way to know when something is amiss. With cloud deployments of applications as microservices on Kubernetes and OpenShift growing, observability is getting a lot of attention. Many applications come with strict guarantees, such as service level agreements (SLA) for downtimes, latency, and throughput, so network-level observability is a highly imperative feature. Network-level observability is provided by several orchestrators, either natively or by using plugins and operators. Recently, eBPF (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) emerged as a popular option to‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 sudo myths debunked
entry.summary:
7 sudo myths debunked Peter Czanik Wed, 08/24/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this Whether attending conferences or reading blogs, I often hear several misconceptions about sudo. Most of these misconceptions focus on security, flexibility, and central management. In this article, I will debunk some of these myths. Many misconceptions likely arise because users know only the basic functionality of sudo. The sudoers file, by default, has only two rules: The root user, and members of the administrative wheel group, can do practically anything using sudo. There are barely any limits, and optional features are not enabled at all. Even this setup is better than sharing the root password, as you can usually follow who did what on your systems using the logs. However, learnin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Your guide to DistSQL's cluster governance capability
entry.summary:
Your guide to DistSQL's cluster governance capability Raigor Jiang Wed, 08/24/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this Apache ShardingSphere 5.0.0-Beta version with DistSQL made the project even more beloved by developers and ops teams for its advantages, such as dynamic effects, no restart, and elegant syntax close to standard SQL. With upgrades to 5.0.0 and 5.1.0, the ShardingSphere community has once again added abundant syntax to DistSQL, bringing more practical features. In this article, the community co-authors will share the latest functions of DistSQL from the perspective of cluster governance. ShardingSphere clusters In a typical cluster composed of ShardingSphere-Proxy, there are multiple compute nodes and storage nodes, as shown in the figure below.
‚Ä¶

entry.title: How I migrated to NetworkManager keyfiles for configuration
entry.summary:
How I migrated to NetworkManager keyfiles for configuration David Both Tue, 08/23/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this NetworkManager was introduced in 2004 to make network configuration more flexible and dynamic. The old SystemV startup shell scripts, of which the interface configuration files were a part, were incapable of handling WiFi, wired, VPNs, broadband modems, and more‚Äîor at least incapable of doing it quickly or efficiently. In a series of articles, I've written about why I'm a fan of NetworkManager and how I've used it. In part 1, I looked at what NetworkManager does and some of the tools it provides for viewing network connections and devices. In that article, I mentioned that NetworkManager does not need interface configuration files for most hosts. Howe‚Ä¶

entry.title: Mentoring as a power multiplier in open source
entry.summary:
Mentoring as a power multiplier in open source Josh Salomon Mon, 08/22/2022 - 03:00
6 readers like this 6 readers like this Many developers struggle with work-life balance. They are overloaded with regular tasks and frequently called upon to solve urgent customer issues. Yet many developers, like me, have ideas they want to promote if only they had time to do so. Sometimes these pet ideas do not make it through the product management feature-selection process. Other times, a developer does not have time to complete the solution end-to-end on their own, yet they know if it could somehow be implemented, the project would benefit. This is where mentoring comes in. Mentorship has many benefits: It helps the mentee's personal development, and it can improve the mentor's self-confidence an‚Ä¶

entry.title: My first impression of GNOME Console on Linux
entry.summary:
My first impression of GNOME Console on Linux Alan Formy-Duval Mon, 08/22/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this New on the GNOME desktop is their terminal emulator application simply named Console. It seems aimed at providing a no-nonsense, stable command-line environment for Linux users. Introducing GNOME Console for Linux
Image by: ‚Äã(Alan Formy-Duval, CC BY-SA 4.0) ‚Äã
The GNOME Console isn't as feature-rich as a lot of other terminals, including the previous GNOME terminal, but I like it and have been using it regularly for the past few months. I enjoy the simplicity of it. I waste time in other terminal emulators configuring fonts, colors, and profiles. Console does have some options and nice integration with the GNOME desktop. I'll start with t‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to Stop Robots From Becoming Racist
entry.summary: Algorithms can amplify patterns of discrimination. Robotics researchers are calling for new ways to prevent mechanical bodies acting out those biases.
